terms.definition: A localized injury to the skin and underlying tissue caused by prolonged pressure, shear, or friction. Often seen in bedridden or otherwise mobility-limited patients.
Also known as a pressure ulcer, is a skin injury that occurs due to prolonged pressure on the skin.
The removal of dead (non-viable), foreign material or contaminated tissue from a wound to promote healing.
Fluid that oozes out of a wound, containing proteins, cells, and debris. Exudate can be clear, yellow, green, or bloody.
New connective tissue formed during wound healing, characterized by a pink or beefy red appearance. Facilitates wound closure in the healing process of secondary intention.
Reducing pressure on affected areas to facilitate healing, often using a specialized device or technique.
A thick, dry, hard, black or brown necrotic tissue that forms a scab on a wound.
Soft, yellowish or whitish necrotic (dead) tissue that may be present in a wound bed.
The formation of a pocket or ledge beneath the intact skin at the wound edge.
Narrow channels extending from the wound bed into surrounding tissue.
A type of dressing that forms a gel-like substance when in contact with wound exudate, promoting a moist wound environment.
Absorbent dressing made from seaweed-derived fibers that absorb exudate and promote healing in heavily draining wounds.
A severe bone infection characterized by inflammation and damage to bone tissue often caused by bacteria.
A condition where veins have problems sending blood from the legs back to the heart, often leading to leg swelling and venous ulcers.
Nerve damage that can result in loss of sensation, particularly common in people with diabetes.
A condition where narrowed arteries reduce blood flow to the limbs, often causing pain and slow wound healing.
The formation of new skin cells at the wound edges to cover the wound.
Softening and breakdown of skin or wound tissue due to prolonged exposure to moisture.
A protective layer formed by a community of bacteria in the wound, which can hinder healing.
The body's natural process of breaking down and removing dead tissue.
